awd_titl_txt: CPS:Medium:Collaborative Research: Safe Learning in Co-robots--Theory, Experiments and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support fundamental research on scalable and safe collaborative cyber physical systems. Specifically, this project will address the question of how to balance adaptability with safety for large human-robot teams. While pre-programmed robots can perform well in a perfectly known and unchanging workspace, accomplishing complex tasks under real-world conditions requires the ability to adapt to unexpected circumstances. This adaptability can be provided using artificial intelligence or machine learning techniques, but the resulting robot behavior becomes less predictable, which in turn makes it difficult to guarantee safe human-robot interactions. This project addresses the challenge of guaranteed safety by using an innovative integration of machine learning with techniques from control theory and nonlinear dynamics. In contrast to current approaches, the methods studied here will be scalable, that is, they will remain practical to implement even when the number of interacting humans and robots become large. Many important applications can benefit from the results of this project, including disaster relief, rescue missions, homeland security, and assisted healthcare. This project will also develop a teaching platform for collaborative human-robot engineering that will be used to teach collaborative robotics in large classes, and to help broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in research.

Robots that collaborate with human partners in a shared physical workspace are called co-robots or cobots. This research will address the fundamental challenge of safety and performance guarantees as collaborative human-robot cyber physical systems move from model-driven control approaches to data-driven methods. In particular, the project will focus on data-rich iterative tasks performed by groups of humans and robots, and dynamically challenging tasks where human-robot and robot-robot interaction forces are complex to model. Statistical learning theory will be merged with predictive control theory using a mix of physics-based and data-driven models in the learning process. In the co-robot cyber physical systems under study, robot and human models will be updated in real-time using data feeds. Within each robot such models will be used by a predictive controller to forecast robot motion and human interaction, and to take corresponding safe and collaborative actions. The new theory resulting from this project will provide statistically rigorous guarantees of performance improvement and safety during the learning process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project, titled "CPS:Medium:Collaborative Research: Safe Learning in Co-robots--Theory, Experiments, and Education," aimed to develop a novel theory for safe learning in collaborative robots (co-robots) and test it on legged and wheeled robots. It addressed the challenge of ensuring safety and performance as co-robots transition from model-driven to data and model-driven systems.

The project embarked on an ambitious journey to merge the worlds of robotics and advanced computational theories, focusing on the safety and efficiency of collaborative robots, commonly known as co-robots. These robots are designed to work alongside humans, making their safety and reliability paramount. The project's achievements span across two fundamental areas.

Firstly, the team innovated by blending predictive control with statistical machine learning. This breakthrough is akin to teaching robots to think ahead while learning from their environment, a significant step in making them safer and more intuitive partners in various settings. Through experiments, robots demonstrated an ability to adapt dynamically to different roles and safely navigate through uncertainties, showcasing an advanced level of interaction between themeself or with humans.

Another significant achievement was in balancing performance with safety. Here, the project delved into the complex world of dynamic games - a theoretical approach to model interactions among independent agents, like robots, who don't necessarily cooperate. The team created a novel method to solve challenging mathematical problems, helping these robots make better decisions in competitive or collaborative scenarios.

The project has pushed the boundaries of what we can expect from collaborative robots. It's not just about robots performing tasks but doing so in a way that is inherently safe, responsive, and in sync with human needs and environments. 

Training and Professional Development

The project provided significant opportunities for training and professional development, especially for PhD students. It fostered an environment of collaborative learning and intellectual exchange, crucial for academic growth. Participation in conferences and seminars enhanced students' visibility in the academic community, expanding their professional networks and future career opportunities.

Broader Impacts and Intellectual Merit

The project's outcomes have broad implications for the development of safe, efficient, and intelligent robotic systems. The advancements in predictive control, machine learning integration, and human-robot interaction contribute significantly to the field of robotics and automation. The project's findings and methodologies not only advance the principal discipline but also have potential applications in other areas involving dynamic, safety-critical systems. The training and professional development aspects of the project also contribute to building human resources in this cutting-edge field.
